While her work intersected with health/education topics, the primary context is her death and memorialization, making 'Obituaries' the most precise classification.

title: Former Rescue Fire Company Chief Jeffery O. Hurley Sr. dies
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Former Rescue Fire Company Chief Jeffery O. Hurley Sr. dies

 January 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 677
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Former Fire Chief Jeffery O. Hurley Sr. lived and breathed the Rescue Fire Company."It was definitely in his heart," said longtime friend and fellow fireman Dorchester County Council Member Ricky Travers.
Hurley, who died Jan. 23 at 68 years old, held a membership with Rescue Fire Company for 47 years, serving in a variety of roles.
He served as president from 1983 through 1985. In 1986, Hurley took on the title of first assistant chief before becoming chief for the first time in 1990. All in all, Hurley served as chief of the fire company from 1990 to 1994, from 1996 to 2002 and from 2004 to 2010.
In 2004, he was made a life member of the fire company.
Travers said Hurley was an advocate who helped move Rescue Fire Company forward.
"He fought with the city to make sure that they knew we were a part of the city and that they had to get the building permits to run through us," Travers said.
According to a social media post from Rescue Fire Company, even after his last term as chief, Hurley would still show up to fire incidents from time to time, sharing his expertise with firemen.
"My phone rang once or twice a week with him," said current Rescue Fire Chief Brad Walters, laughing.
Walters, who in his first years with the company worked under Hurley, said Hurley was a "strong-willed" leader who fought for what the department needed.
"He was the cornerstone of where we are and how we operate now," Walters said. "Every piece of apparatus inside the fire house at this time has his name attached to it in some manner. Whether he was on the committee, whether he was the chief overseeing it. Specifically, some of the engines. He fought extremely hard with the city to purchase the needed equipment for our department."
Walters said Hurley was also "kind hearted." He said he remembers Hurley helping him out and giving him side jobs when he was younger.
"He was there to make sure everyone excelled around him," Walters said.
Hurley served his community in more ways than one. He spent his career at Jess Jr's & Son's, a collision repair shop and towing service in Cambridge. He served in multiple positions as a member of the Cambridge Yacht Club, ultimately becoming the club's commodore.
His involvement spanned from the Cambridge Rotary Club, to the Maryland State Firefighters Association, to the Maryland Fire Chiefs Association to the Towing and Recovery Professionals of Maryland.
"He was a leader in the community," Travers said.
Hurley will be remembered for his friendship. Martin Pepper, who met Hurley in 1986 and served multiple years as assistant chief when Hurley was chief, said Hurley was very important to him.
"He was a very good friend to me," Pepper said. "Good friend to a lot of people, but we were very close."
During a Cambridge City Council meeting on Jan. 27, Commission President Sputty Cephas talked about his friendship with Hurley.
"There wasn't a time that we couldn't go to Jeff for whatever," he said, later adding, that Hurley will "truly" be missed.
Hurley is survived by his son, Jeffery O. Hurley Jr. (Sarah); bonus sons Joshua Bauguess (Kayla) and Noah Bauguess (Deanna); brother Jed M. Hurley Sr. (Brenda); nephew Jed "J.R." Hurley Jr. (Abbie); niece Amanda Jo Hurley Hallowell (Logan); great nieces Abriella Hallowell, Leilani Hallowell and Maddie Hurley; great nephew Jed M. Hurley III and God children Brandon Hall, JR Moore and Maddie Fleming.
Hurley is preceded in death by his parents, daughter Jessica Anne Hurley and his brother, Jay L. Hurley.
Services will be held Friday, Jan. 31. A visitation will be held from 10 a.m. to noon at the Public Safety Building at 8 Washington St. in Cambridge. The visitation will be followed by a firefighter memorial service at noon at the Public Safety Building. After that, a brief procession will pass by Jess Jr's & Son's and the old fire house at 307 Gay St. before entering Dorchester Memorial Park for burial services. A wake will be held after the burial at the East New Market Volunteer Fire Department.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the death of a former fire chief, detailing his service and memorial, which fits the Obituaries category. While his role in public safety is mentioned, the primary focus is on his passing and legacy, making Obituaries the best match.

title: Robert Earl Price, poet, playwright and arts advocate dies
author: Staff Writer
content:
Robert Earl Price, poet, playwright and arts advocate dies

 May 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 591
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Robert Earl Price, a celebrated poet, playwright, and champion of African American culture, died April 16 at the age of 83. Price, a former screenwriter during the Black Arts Movement and an influential figure in the arts community, spent the final 18 years of his life in Chestertown, where he co-founded the Kent County Poetry Festival, worked extensively with the Kent Cultural Alliance and contributed to preserving local African American history.Price was a prolific writer with several books of poetry, including "Wise Blood" and "Blood Flow", the latter of which earned him the William Meredith Award. His work transcended genres, with over a dozen of his plays produced, including notable works like "Blue Monk", which was commissioned for the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta. His plays were performed internationally, with productions in Johannesburg, Berlin, and across the United States.
Price's career spanned several decades and locations. Born in Atlanta, Georgia, he studied at Clark Atlanta University and later moved to Los Angeles, where he joined the Black Arts Movement and contributed to the L.A. Rebellion. He received the prestigious William Wyler Fellowship for Screenwriting from the American Film Institute, and collaborated with well-known figures such as Norman Lear and Alex Haley on the TV series "Palmerstown, U.S.A." His work earned him an NAACP Image Award and recognition for his activism, including co-founding the Black Anti-Defamation Coalition in 1980.
In addition to his achievements in screenwriting and theater, Price was a dedicated educator. He served as Artist-in-Residence at Washington College in Chestertown, where he wrote and produced two new plays. His work also contributed to understanding slavery during the Revolutionary Era, particularly through productions such as "The Unlading", a work that gave better perception of the role of slavery in Eastern Shore history.
Price's poetry and plays often incorporated jazz and blues, blending these musical forms with themes of resistance and social justice. His work explored African American history, celebrated cultural icons, and pushed the boundaries of traditional theater. His friends and colleagues remember him for his sharp wit, deep wisdom, and unwavering belief in the power of art to challenge the status quo.
Christopher Ames, president emeritus of Russell Sage College, worked with Price in both Atlanta and Chestertown. "I first met Robert Earl when I was serving on the board of 7Stages, the innovative theater company in Atlanta, where he was the Playwright in Residence. Later, when I moved to Chestertown to serve as Provost and Dean at Washington College, I was thrilled to hire Robert Earl as a part-time Artist in Residence in the Drama Department," Ames said. "He and his wife embraced this community, and Robert Earl's impact was immediate and lasting. Together, we conceived the Kent County Poetry Festival with the help of Tom Martin and The Book Plate. Robert Earl was not just a co-founder; he was the heartbeat of the festival, present and actively organizing every year until this last April, when he was on his deathbed. His passion for poetry, community, and the arts was unmatched, and his legacy will continue to influence the festival and the arts scene here for years to come."
A devoted father and grandfather, Price is survived by his partner of 33 years, Carol Colgate; three children, Dhati Price, Makini Jones (Elzia), and Mshinda Jones (Lisa); five grandchildren, Ariana, Phylicia, Philip, Jamal, and Bashiri Halan; and one great-grandson, Brayden.
A memorial service will be held in Chestertown June 21.
Price's legacy as a poet, playwright, and cultural advocate will continue to inspire and shape the Eastern Shore arts community for years to come.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is primarily an obituary detailing the life and achievements of Robert Earl Price, a poet and arts advocate. While his work in the arts is central, the structure and purpose of the article align most directly with the 'Obituaries' category. 'Arts & Culture' and 'Entertainment' are secondary but relevant due to his professional contributions.
